text: Ariane, that's awesome. :-)Chiara, it took about 20 hours to create the survey and analyze the results -- I'm sorry, but with our semester starting on Monday we just don't have time to redo it!

Last September, with exactly the same course material, we ran a workload survey in week 3. That survey asked how many hours were spent on these tasks: Week 1 lectures Exercise 1 In week 1, Python study with other materials, such as online books Week 2 lectures Exercise 2 Assignment 1 In week 2, Python study with other materials, such as online books The survey also asked how much programming experience people had: no experience written a few small programs or tried to take another programming course but didn't complete it completed an introductory programming course significant programming experience Almost 12,000 people completed the survey. Here are the results: 4176 people have no experience in programming: beginner results 3335 people have a little bit of programming experience: only-a-little-experience results 2681 people have completed a programming course: one-course-taken results 1806 people consider themselves to be experienced programmers: experienced results 11989 people responded: combined results The biggest takeaway for us was just how much of spread there was in hours spent -- it's huge! Add up the hours range for the biggest bars, though, and you come out quite close to the 6-8 hour time estimate.

No need to apologize! The description in the handout for get_seconds says this: The parameter is a number of seconds since midnight. Return the number of seconds that have elapsed since midnight as seen on a clock. (This means that the return value should be in the range 0 to 59, inclusive.)Your code instead returns a number in the range 0-23, because you're calling function to_24_hour_clock, which converts a number of hours to a time on a 24 hour clock (it uses % 24 to do this). Advanced discussion here. You'll understand it all by the end of the course.Passing an argument to a parameter has the same effect as an assignment statement: the parameter ends up containing the memory address of the value. If that value is mutable, such as a list, then you can change its contents:>>> def f(lst):...    lst.append(3)... >>> L = [1, 2]>>> f(L)>>> L[1, 2, 3]In your example, though, you're not mutating the value itself; instead, in your function body you reassign to parameter x. Also, that parameter x is not the same x outside the function; the one outside is a global variable.Is that enough explanation? I'm happy to keep going!

I play in the Society for Creative Anachronism [http://sca.org/], a group that studies medieval life. It's an odd set of rules -- we use rattan instead of metal, so perhaps "stick fighting" would be closer. Because we use rattan, though, we can hit full force. It's not just armoured combat, though: there's everything from weaving to glassblowing to cooking using medieval recipes. A favourite event is Pennsic [http://pennsicwar.org/], a 2-week camping event with 10,000 people that happens in western Pennsylvania. (Best shopping ever.)Typical scotches: Dalwhinnie (especially in the summer), Balvenie, Dalmore, Oban. I find heavy peat to be a bit too much. You?

This is advanced. Please don't worry if you're completely lost with this post. You'll understand most of it by the end of the course.In week 7, you're going to learn about dictionaries, which allows you to define mappings between keys and values, much like a regular dictionary maps words to definitions. (This is directly relevant to the question in this thread! Don't worry if it doesn't make complete sense yet; come back to this after week 7.)Here, 'a' is mapped to 'b', and 'c' is mapped to 'd':>>> a_dictionary = {'a': 'b', 'c': 'd'}We can look up a value given a key:>>> a_dictionary['a'] 'b'The reason this is relevant is because Python uses dictionaries to keep track of variables and their values. Every running function (and the Python shell itself) is given a dictionary to keep track of the values of its parameters and local variables. You can access these various dictionaries using built-in function locals:>>> my_variable = 'abracadabra' >>> locals() {'__doc__': None, '__package__': None, 'my_variable': 'abracadabra', '__name__': '__main__', '__builtins__': <module 'builtins' (built-in)>, '__loader__': <class '_frozen_importlib.BuiltinImporter'>} Notice the 'my_variable': 'abracadabra' entry! Python turns variables into strings and saves them in a dictionary. And that is why variables are separate from their values in Python.For the rest of the entries, anything starting and ending with 2 underscores is special to Python.  Notice the '__builtins__': <module 'builtins' (built-in)> entry -- that's how Python accesses the built-in functions.

That's actually a tricky question to answer because Python keeps some common values in memory but recycles less-common ones. Small integers (-5 to 256, I think?) are kept around, or cached, but everything else is recycled, or garbage collected, or "garbage collected". Some strings are also cached.

Whoops! That "stores" should be "contains" -- I've just fixed it.Background: to store something is to put it somewhere. To contain something is to hold it. Python stores memory addresses inside variables, and variables contain those memory addresses. It's not the variable that is doing the storing.

Close! 'variable' is more general that 'parameter': in the code below, there are two variables, x and y. def f(y): return y * 2 x = 3 f(x) y is also a parameter, but x is not. Also, x is used as an argument in function call f(x). A parameter is a variable that appears between the parentheses in a function header, and an argument is an expression that appears between the parentheses of a function call.

Every programmer needs a mental model (not necessarily visual) of what happens as a program executes -- otherwise, they wouldn't . The visualizer presents a model that I and quite a few other programmers think in as we program. Any model that accurately predicts program execution is fine! However, any correct model will match exactly what the visualizer presents, so if you have a model that doesn't match the one in the visualizer, it is very likely that there is a misunderstanding.

Why do I have a DisabledBuiltinError? You're probably trying to call the open function from your code. Notice that none of the function docstrings say that any of the arguments passed in to any of the functions are file names. The type contracts list arguments as being of type "file open for reading", not "str" as would the case if we wanted you to open any files. Instead, when testing your code, you should open the file in the shell and call your functions, passing in that opened file.

These two concepts are quite different:Some objects, such as lists, are mutable.Variables can be reassigned. Reassigning a variable, as you do in the code above, makes that variable point to a different object. That is different than changing the contents of the object that a variable points to.Does that difference make sense?

I think you'd agree that clarity in documentation is important; part of that is choosing a convention, and the convention we're using is that we're not using parentheses on the return type.(It's surely a bit pedantic of me, but I believe that teaching about code style is part of teaching about programing.)

I took a look at your answers, and it looks like for a few questions you provided a type (float, for example) rather than a value, and the questions were asking you to provide values. (Had we wanted the type, we would have asked something like "what is the type of the value that x refers to").

In programming, "return" has a specific meaning: produce a value as a result of a function call. So the phrase "return the number to the screen" isn't in programming-speak, and we'll never use it like that.Function print changes the pixels on your screen; it doesn't return a value (other than None).

Numbers like 2.3 will never be returned by the function -- there are never a fractional number of vowels. When writing a contract, it's better to be as specific as possible with each type.
Your return statement should be indented as well:def area(base, height): '''(number, number) -> number Return the area of a triangle with dimensions base and height. ''' return base * height / 2

Anon, that's because in the video, the body of the function is not compacted in the return statement. The calculation is split onto several lines of code:

That is because when you reach a return statement, the function immediately exits. No more code from the body of the function is executed after that. In that particular code fragment, the execution flow will never reach the return False statement if the temperature was equal to 22.5.

Gerard, When you use the "Run Module" functionality of IDLE, it's pretty much the same thing as pasting the code into the shell, except it does a quick Syntax check on the file first. There's a modified version of the import statement that produces a similar result in Python: from module import * However, doing this is sometimes considered bad practice. If you have previously defined a function and the module contains a function with the same name, the function you had will be silently replaced by the function in module, which can trigger unexpected behavior.

Well, when Python evaluates a boolean expression, the last thing evaluated becomes the value of that expression. >>> True and 'T''T'>>> False and 'T'False>>> False or 'T''T' Recall the rules for evaluating boolean expressions: From left to right and binds more strongly than or. (It has higher precedence) If the left hand side of an and expression is False, the right hand side is not evaluated The right hand side of an or expression is only evaluated if the left hand side is False. And there's an extra rule: if a string shows up in place of a boolean value, it's considered False if it's the empty string '' and True if it's not. So in the code nuc == 'A' and 'T' if the left hand side is True, because it's an and operator, the right hand side is evaluated, it's value is 'T' so it becomes the value for the expression and because what follows Is the right hand side of an or expression, it's not evaluated. However if nuc is not equal to 'A' then the whole and expression evaluates to False and the right hand side of the or expression Is then evaluated, etc...
After checking it out again, Kundula above was right on the mark, kudos.

I'm gonna try and come up with an acceptable response, but I think that ultimately, this would be better handled by an instructor. There is actually some value to the concept of not "concern[ing] yourself with how it does this". In a lot of situations, you won't be able to know such a thing, and will have to use the tools at your disposal either way. To illustrate my point, I'm gonna try and explain how the longer function would do it: It would be a Python function that calls the len() built-in Python function twice, and compares each calls with a comparison operator. It would then, based on the result of that comparison, return the string passed as argument that has the biggest length. Please note that at the time of AK's posting, we were still in Week 2, so in order to answer the "how", he would have had to introduce Week 3 concepts. Now, that was a rather short-to-explain example, but in the future, you will have to use tools to solve problems, and you won't, at all, be able to know how they work. During the second Week of the course, I coded a crude tool in Python to help with producing the PDF versions of the in-video quizzes. I did that because without the tool, the process of generating said quizzes would have been extremely painful: Take three screenshots for each question, (question, correct answer, explanation)Manually cut each image so that only the interesting part of the screen would remain in the image.Create a new file to hold that "cut" version of each image.Name each new file in a sequential manner.Convert each cut file to PDFsGlue each of those PDF files together to produce the final PDF documentNow that I have the tool, I can just take screenshots and run the tool to produce the final PDF. To code that tool, I used a Python module named "PyPNG". I had to use a number of functions from that module, and the point of the exercise was to do less work, not more. So I consulted the module documentation for each function, and did not concern myself with how they worked, only with what they were supposed to do, and how I was supposed to use them and build on their work. That kind of scenario is, as I understand it, one of the main points of the concept of "function reuse". I think the whole point of the exercise, is to help students figure out what information is important and what information they can safely ignore.I hope I managed to answer your question somewhat. If I didn't, please don't hold that against me, and please keep in mind that the CTAs in this course are people who try and help however they can but were never actually trained for this.

I think that it's kind of an old-fashioned point of view but everyone has a different opinion on that one. I just can't shake the feeling that writing: def range_check(x, lower, upper): if x < lower: return "Below range" if lower <= x <= upper: return "In range" return "past range"Is much simpler than writing:def range_check(x, lower, upper): if x < lower: output = "Below range" elif lower <= x <= upper: output = "In range" else: output = "past range" return outputI feel like the output is an unnecessary step, that in the first function there's only one possible path of execution for whatever argument is passed anyway.

When the line return g(y) is executed, y is first evaluated and replaced with its value: the object 1. Then, the function g is called with 1 as an argument, and inside of the function call, the parameter x is made to point to the object 1. In python, the memory management model is designed so that existing objects are not automatically duplicated, but reused when possible, whereas in some other language, each parameter would end up in a truly "local" variable. At the point in the execution where your screenshot was taken, both y (Edit: the y in the frame of the function f) and x are pointing to the same object, value 1. If you step forward in the execution, you'll see that the object 1 cease to exist when the f() function call returns, because the value is not needed anymore.
Yes, that's because the function does not return a value. It prints it.

Hi Basically, everything in a logic block (Here, that would be a function body) must have the same indentation. That means that after a def statement, every line must be deported to the right by a constant number of space characters. def dummy_function(lhs, rhs): ''' <-- note how the dummy docstring is indented with four spaces? ''' # And here we can start to write code, still with four space indent. lhs += 2 rhs -= 4 output = str(lhs) output += "You can leave empty lines, but not if you type your function in the shell!" output += str(rhs) return 42# <-- And now that you're done with the function, you can break the indentation.

The quiz is not wrong, but I get why it might be confusing: When the function is called at the moment of the assignment, the sum of the numbers is printed. It is not however, returned. The fact that the sum appears on the screen is merely a side-effect. Because the value is not returned, the function exits, and automatically returns None. If you're still not convinced, check this out: >>> def sum(number1, number2):... print(number1 + number2)... >>> result = sum(1, 3)4>>> print(result)None>>> Cheers

Hey, sorry about that. The way you choose to implement the functions is entirely up to you, each function can actually be written so as to not depend on any other functions. It is recommended to use to_24_hour_clock because it makes you practice function reuse at least once in the Assignment, but again, it's up to you. Both ways to go about it have their own advantages: If you go with function reuse, you'll minimize the risk of introducing bugs in your code. If you go with independent functions, troubleshooting using the autograder will be easier. As for get_hours, get_minutes, and get_seconds, it is important to understand that the values those functions should return are restricted in range, much like it would be on a digital clock: That would be 15 hours, 5 minutes, 40 seconds. You would never see on that clock something like "25 hours, 70 minutes, 61 seconds".

Hello AgnieszkaSure, I'm gonna tell you why I would recommend Python over Java for an introductory programming course, please keep in mind that this is my own personal opinion though, not a concerted answer from the course staff. 1 - Python allows for quick experimentation and therefore is Fun. With a capital F. Being an interpreted language, you don't have to perform a compile step when you want to run a program, so you can change your code, and execute it right away.That reduces the chance of modifications to the code not being reflected at execution time, I can't tell you how many times I forgot to recompile a Java or C++ program and didn't immediately understood what I did wrong.The fact that you can use it as a quick and dirty calculator is also most helpful when in the classroom. 2 - Python has a very rich standard library and is easy to use It allows the user to do a great deal of things without always having to rely on third party libraries.It is also ideal to build quick and dirty tools that will make your life easier.I use it (amongst other things) to create the PDF versions of the in-video quizzes each week.I described some parts of the process here. 3 - Python removes the need for the user to constantly worry about resources management Memory allocation is a very important thing to understand when you're a full blown CS major, but for most users that just want to have fun writing small and non-critical programs, this is an added layer of complexity that is not strictly necessary. 4 - Python is beautiful, forces good programming habits onto beginners and the documentation process is supported by its design My personal favorite.There is a lot of cool things in the Python syntax.That makes for easy-to-read code, both for teachers evaluating homework and for students reading example code.The control of the logic flow is done through indentation, and that's very useful, I went into some details about that here. I'm sure there's a lot of other valid reasons to use Python, but those are the main selling points for me, and that's why yes, without a doubt, I would recommend Python over Java for an introductory course. Cheers

Stephen, actually that's not quite how it would go: Nothing inside a function body can be executed after the program flow has reached a return statement. A function always returns one single value, this is true in any programming language that I know of, not only Python. This is the reason why the elif statements are not necessary here. Actually, the last if statement himself is not necessary, you could write:   if scheduled_time == estimated_time:       return 'on time'   if scheduled_time < estimated_time:       return 'delayed'   return 'early' And the function would behave in exactly the same way. There's only three different cases we're concerned about regarding the values of scheduled_time and estimated_time. If we ever reach the second return statement, it's because the first condition was not met, or else the function would have exited at the moment it would have reached the first return statement. And for the same reason, if we ever reach the third return statement, it would mean that the first two conditions checked were not met. Does that make sense? Cheers

The -1 % 24 = 23 bit is due to the mathematical properties of the modulo operator, actually this is one thing to watch for when you start a new programming language: not all language use the same definition of modulo operator. I once lost an hour while coding a bit of C# because of that. But anyway, the other thing to know is that this is heavily used in Video Games. Consider an "Asteroids" kind of old retro video game: you are commanding an alien space battleship in a "screen" that is 24 positions wide. When you are at position 23, right before colliding with the right side of the screen, your position on the screen is 23 % 24 = 23 . When you collide with the screen, your position is now 24 % 24 = 0: you reappear on the left side of the screen. When you are at position 0, on a collision course with the left side of the screen, your position is 0 % 24 = 0. And then again, when you go through the left side of the screen, your position is -1 % 24 = 23: you reappear on the right side of the screen. Cheers

I noticed your "poor man's swap" and I was curious so I tested it and here's the result: XOR version:for i in range(0, 1000000): a = i b = i + (i % 9) xor = a ^ b # a ^= xor # poor man's SWAP b ^= xor #Result:ouroumov@Adcap:~/Desktop$ time python3 try.pyreal	0m0.857suser	0m0.848ssys	0m0.008sTuple unpacking version:for i in range(0, 1000000): a = i b = i + (i % 9) a, b = b, aResult:ouroumov@Adcap:~/Desktop$ time python3 try.pyreal	0m0.512suser	0m0.496ssys	0m0.012sIt seems like Tuple unpacking is the "poorest" man version.

Why do I get a SyntaxError when I try to define a function?That's probably because you forgot to add a new empty line after you finished writing the function body.Here are the important points:>>> def f(x): # <-- Don't forget the colon at the end!... return x ** 2 # <-- Don't forget to indent this line with four spaces left of "return"!... # <-- Leave this line empty!>>> f(4) # <-- Now you can call the function!16

How is a parameter different from an argument?A parameter is a variable that appears between the parentheses in a function header, and an argument is an expression that appears between the parentheses of a function call.>>> def area(base, height): # <-- Here, 'base' and 'height' are parameters.... return base * height / 2... >>> h = 4>>> area(3, h) # <-- Here, area is called with the arguments '3' and 'h'.6.0
They delimit character strings. >>> def concat(lhs, rhs):... return(lhs + " . " + rhs)... >>> concat("Python", "rocks")'Python . rocks'This is more of a Week 2 material.

That's just wrong!Well, the other way to think about it is that it's extremely close to be true. This is a /!\ complex topic /!\ that involves the way floating point numbers are represented in memory. This is not specific to Python, you will see the same kind of things in many languages.If you're really curious you can check out the official explanation of the Python FAQ.

In any case, do not be afraid to ask a question People in the course staff are a really nice bunch, and there is a boatload of students here that made it their mission in life to help others. What follow is only some suggestions on how to ask for help. Step 1 - Ask a RoBoT     (Search the forum) Common practice on the Internet.With over 65 000 students (and counting) registered for this course, it is likely that someone ran into the same problem, so take a few minutes to search the forums using keywords and Check the FAQ. Step 2 - Choose where to ask If you don't want to ask in English or if you feel like you can express your problem better in your native tongue Consider asking in a language-specific study group.The Arabic Study Group. اذا احتجتم للمساعدة، تعالوا واسألوا هناThe Dutch Study Group. Als je hulp nodig hebt, vraag het hier.The Spanish Study Group. Si necesitas ayuda, preguntanos aquí.The German Study Group. Wenn Ihr Hilfe braucht, fragt uns hier.The Chinese Study Group. 如果有任何問題，歡迎到這裡發問！-- 如果有任何问题，欢迎到这里发问！The French-Speaking Study group. Si vous avez besoin d'aide, venez demander ici !The Russian Study Group. Если вам нужна помощь, задавайте свои вопросы здесь.The Italian Study Group. Se vi serve aiuto, chiedete qui!The Brazilian Study Group. Se você precisa de ajuda, venha e nós pergunte aqui. If you decide to ask in English, choose the right sub-forum. The forums here have a lot of sections and sub-sections, each with its own purpose. If you prefer Facebook, You can also get help on the official Facebook Study Group. Step 3 - Watch out for the special case of the [Platform Problem] If you can determine that your problem is of such nature (because it's obvious, because nobody could help you, because someone told you so, because you tried everything else, etc...), then you don't have a lot of choices left, but if you are very motivated, you can submit a bug report.Here is a real live example of a problem another student encountered in which I explain in detail the process of submitting such a report. Step 4 - Choose a meaningful title that will also help competent people notice the thread It is generally better to start a new thread rather than posting in an existing one, that way your question will be more visible than if you post in a slightly related thread with a lot of comments.If you have a coding problem, then a lot of students will be able to help you, but if your issue appears to be related to your environment (Example: you have trouble installing IDLE) then mentioning the Operating System you use (Windows, OSX, Linux flavor, etc) is a good idea.I am totally useless when it comes to Apple computers, or Windows 8. Step 5 - Describe the issue in details Give some context, explain how you got there.If the problem is related to a video lecture, say which one.If it is a programming issue, then give some code using code blocks.If you're not sure where in the code is the error, give all your code using a pastebin-type website such as the Debian Pastebin. Take care of not breaching the Honor Code when the coding problem concerns the graded Exercises / Assignments. It's OK to post code that you know don't workIt's not OK to post code that worksYou can also think about posting links to screen captures of the bug in action, using a picture hosting site such as imm.io Step 6 - Post your question and check for an answer after 5 minutes The course forum is a very active place.Sometime you will get an answer, or a request for additional details literally in seconds. Step 7 - [The end]: post to say if / when your problem is solved That way people who helped you can move on to helping others.If you started a new thread to post your question, please mark it as resolved. Hello Renée Python uses indentation to delimit logic blocks inside a program.A function definition is such a logic block: Everything after the function's header that is part of the function must be indented by the exact same amount of whitespaces characters.When you start writing a logic block, you end the first line of that block with a colon :.Every statement coming after a colon and inside the logic block must be properly indented to the right.If the immediately following statement is not indented, the interpreter will raise a SyntaxError. When you break the level of indentation, it tells the Python interpreter that the following instructions are not part of the previous logic block.Because of that, you'll sometime see other SyntaxErrors when you broke the indentation too soon, due to the fact that some statements, such as a return statement, cannot appear outside of the logic block. In about a day, when Week 3 goes live, another kind of logic block will be introduced: the if statement.In the same way we indent the content of function definitions, we'll have to indent the content of the if statement. In a lot of other programing languages, logic blocks are defined by opening and closing sequences, so the indentation of their content is usually not mandatory.Because it's not mandatory, people can feel free to indent in a very irregular manner, and that tends to produce code that is very hard to read. Cheers

Indeed, this is what functions are for.

When you assign a variable to another, it's not the address of the variable that becomes the value for the new variable, but instead it's the value referred to by the first variable. Here's an illustrative snippet: >>> Tree = 4>>> hex(id(Tree)) # Tree contains that address'0x8bb9e0'>>> Forest = 7>>> hex(id(Forest)) # Forest contains that address'0x8bba40'>>> Forest = Tree>>> hex(id(Forest)) # Now Forest contains the address that that was previously in 'Tree''0x8bb9e0'>>> Forest4>>> Tree = 8>>> Forest4

Hi That's normal, the execution of the code you save in a new file will not show on the shell when you restart. However it will be executed and any name defined during that execution will then be available in your shell. You can then use the functions you defined in the new file in the shell. You can test that with the following steps: Close IDLE after saving your work.Start IDLE, and then go to the menu File -> Open and select your file. It will open in a new window.In the new window, use the menu Run -> Run module You can now use the functions defined in the file in the shell.

Those are rounding errors. Because a computer does not have the infinite amount of memory necessary to perfectly represent a number such as 2/3, python has to round up the values somehow. Doing that introduces errors, and errors tend to pile up, but this is usually tolerable unless your code needs extreme levels of precision.

That's how you exit a logic block in Python: you break indentation to return to the previous indentation level. Here, the previous indentation level was the one inside the function's body, where the if keyword was placed. For the same reason, you can write multiple function definition in a given file, by breaking indentation and returning to the first character on the left of the line, thus exiting the function's body.

Hey Anon What you can do is try this: Here's an example call for the function seconds_difference in Step 2: >>> seconds_difference(3600.0, 1800.0)-1800.0 This is the example call that's written inside the documentation string in the file a1.pyDo this in IDLE: >>> time_1 = 3600.0>>> time_2 = 1800.0 Now, you have two variables, each with a value, and it's the same values they would have in the function during the example call. Then, go back to the Week 1 videos about Python as a calculator, and the videos about Variables. You can try and combining those variables into expressions, using the arithmetic operators from the Python as a calculator video. Example: >>> time_1 + time_25400.0 time_1 + time_2 is an expression, and it is evaluated when you press enter as the value 5400.0. Now, there's other operators available, including the minus - operator. Try and use it instead of plus, and see what result you get. Try different orders for the variables, with different operators, like time_2 + time_1, and so on. When you get an expression that evaluates to -1800.0 (the result of the function call in the example) then you'll most likely have the correct expression for the function. Then, go back to your a1.py file, and write a return statement for the function, right under the documentation string, and with the same indentation as the documentation string (so 4 spaces character on the left of the keyword return). On the right of the keyword return, leave a space then write the expression you found that evaluates to -1800.0. Then, save the file using either the menu or CTRL + S. Next, either use Run -> Run module or copy all the code for the function seconds_difference by selecting it then using CTRL + C, and paste it into IDLE using CTRL + V, then hit enter until you get back the prompt >>>.  Once that's done, go back to your file, and copy an example call, then paste it into IDLE, and check that it returns the correct value according to the Examples. Do that for each example call in the documentation string. When that's done and you got the right value each time, go to the Assignment page, click the Submit button on the bottom-right. Using the dialog that opens, select your file a1.py, and make sure that is the correct file that you modified. Then, click Open, and then Submit again. When that's done, go back to the Assignment page, and click the "View" button at the bottom right, and you should see that your function seconds_difference passed some tests, and got you some points. Then, go back to your code, and re-read the instructions about the function from the handout, read again the function description from the documentation string, and understand why the code you wrote make sense. Then, you should be able to go to Step 3.

Try and think about this the way a normal human - not a program would. A human would look at every character in the string more or less one by one, and say the sequence is not valid as soon as he sees an illegal character, if he can't find an illegal character in the string, he would say the sequence is valid. In near pseudo code, the same thing can be described like this: # For each character in the sequence... # ...check if the character is illegal, and if it is: # say the sequence is illegal, and stop.# You've now reached the end of the sequence without stopping: say the sequence is legal.Now you can transcribe that into Python code, and it will work.

Hello Dimitar Disclaimer: /!\ most of what follows will make no sense to most beginners reading this thread. /!\ I'm gonna try and answers those questions the best I can, but sadly I'm not a C expert, so pardon me if that doesn't do the trick. 1) In Python you can consider every variable to be a pointer to a value. Variables have no type, but values do. You can consider every variable to be the Python equivalent of a (void *) type pointer in C. 2) In Python a function can return different kinds of values depending on what happens inside the function's body. Those built-in functions are implemented so that it returns the correct kind of value: >>> max(1.2, 2.4)2.4>>> max(1, 2)2>>> max(1.3, 2)2>>> max(1, 2.3)2.3 3) Unused memory locations are collected when deemed appropriate (Check out Kevin's link or this one.) Here's a post where I tried to illustrate a related mechanism. Cheers

I see a lot of people struggling with Assignment 1 and pasting the raw feedback summary over and over again. This post is to explain that the feedback is not only there to tell you that something failed, but also what failed, and how. If you don't see well enough the screenshots, copy the image address by right clicking and choosing the correct option in the contextual menu, then paste it in the address bar in a new tab. I made some modifications to my personal a1.py file in order to make it fail some tests and illustrate my point, please excuse my poor editing skills: To get to the Feedback, click on the view button: You're gonna see the awful stuff that people enjoy posting on the forums because they think that it contains meaningful information.However, here's the kicker: that's not all there is to it!On that page, please direct your attention to the "mid-summaries" link. And then click it. This will show you a more detailed version of the feedback.When considering the next screenshot, please note that every function that you are supposed to write is assigned a series of tests, referred to as "test_<function name>". Here, you can see that two of my functions failed: seconds_difference and hours_difference.I only introduced one error in my code. I'm gonna let you speculate but at that point it's pretty fair to assume that one function failing caused the other one to fail.This is specific to the code I wrote for the Assignment, and it does not mean that if your function seconds_diff fails, your function hours_diff should fail too. Now hey, we're well on our way to having a clue about what went wrong!Now is the time to get slammed in the face by the overwhelming amount of informations you get when clicking the "Details" link on the top right corner of the table. Brace yourself: this is rough! As you can see, for each function a number of different tests is executed.In that particular case, it seems that all the tests in the docstrings are run, and then some. Now you can get even more information by clicking on the "FAILURE" link on the right of each test report.You'll get something like this: This gives you somewhat human-readable information about what was tested and what went wrong. For the story, I introduced a random * 0.999 in my code to derail the calculation that the grader performed. The value on the right '12.1654etc..' is what my function returned, and the value on the left is what was expected. Now, if you followed the Handout's recommendations and submitted your completed steps as you went, you should be able to get a grip on what's going on, or at least where the problem is. I hope this will be useful to some of you.I will update this post with a second example in a while.Cheers

Following is the game plan I've been thinking about for the Guild, it is open to discussion so don't hesitate if you have other helpful ideas: Stuff you can do without having to write anything: 1 - Upvote helpful posts you notice in the forums. An helpful post is one who guides the person asking a question to the answer while not introducing concepts he doesn't know yet.This will encourage helpers to help more.There is only a handful of reason why you would ever need to downvote anyone, please be careful to not downvote people expressing their own point of view, even if it does not help or totally misses the point. Stuff you can do that needs actual keyboard action: 0 - Be careful not to breach the honor code when you answer a question Hint to the answer, help the student reach it by himself. 1 - When you answer a question, watch out for cases where people obviously never read this thread or are asking questions that are already answered in the FAQ. When you encounter such a case, invite the person asking the question to take a look at those threads (try and be nice about it), and if he is asking about a specific FAQ item, provide him with a link to that specific item. (You can link to individual posts / comments - the link is on the right of the poster's id) This will help educate your fellow students on the best practice when asking for help, and will reduce the probability that such questions from the same student appear in the weeks to come. 2 - If you know of a link to a specific thread where a question is discussed at length feel free to direct the student asking about that subject to that thread. 3 - When you actually have to answer the question yourself, format it nicely. Use code blocks for code or shell snippets, use bold text for important words, etc... 4 - If you feel like it, you can go back on your posts when you know they helped and sign those with a link to this thread. Example: Anon - The Guild This will recursively help us recruit more members. Stuff you can do if you can come on the IRC channel: Drop me a line in private when needed. 1 - Hunt down FAQ items. We are currently late in setting up the Week 2 FAQ. We'll start working on it but any help is welcomed. 2 - If you stumble upon Honor Code violations, alert us so we can edit the posts. If I'm not connected or afk, you can alert nitish` or d4vey if you see them. The guidelines about posting code samples or attempted answers for the Exercises or Assignments are as follow: If someone posts an answer / code that he knows is right, then that's a problem and you can alert us / notify the poster. If someone posts an answer / code that is wrong, then that's not a problem. If someone posts an answer / code that he think is wrong but isn't, that's a problem too and you can alert us / notify the poster. If someone, after seeing a wrong answer, posts some helpful advice without giving the answer such as "Please, be careful what operator you choose to use", that's not a problem. If someone, after seeing a wrong answer, posts something like "Just replace '/' with '//' and that's right" then that's a problem too and you should either alert us or notify the poster.   I know this is a fuzzy line, but please use your best judgment.

>>> 3 - - 36>>> This is because of the Operator Precedence. Positive, negative have highest precedence. When the arithmetic expression is scanned, the python grammar stipulates that it can be of the forms:a_expr ::= m_expr | a_expr "+" m_expr | a_expr "-" m_exprThe matching case is the one on the right because the first two tokens that the interpretor scanned are "3" and "-".When the scan starts on the m_expr on the right, the set of rules is:m_expr ::= u_expr | m_expr "*" u_expr | m_expr "//" u_expr | m_expr "/" u_expr | m_expr "%" u_exprWe are then entering the first case because the first item scanned is a "-", so none of the other case match.Finally, we're encountering the rules for a u_expr:u_expr ::= power | "-" u_expr | "+" u_expr | "~" u_exprSide note: see how we're deeper in the grammar? This is why the unary "-" has higher precedence than the binary "-".We're entering the second case of that grammar snippet because the first token is still "-", and what's on it's left must be another u_expr.The second time around the only choice is the first one because none of the other possible first tokens are on the input stream.And the rule becomes...power ::= primary ["**" u_expr]There's a few more steps involved, but the point is, the expression is valid Python syntax. Side note: when there is no way to process the input stream using the Python grammar, that's when a SyntaxError is raised.For those that didn't run away and that are still interested, I recommend Pr. Ullman's class "Automata".

This post gives a few tips that every one should now about.Mac users: for you, "CTRL" means "command" Chapter 1 - Shortcut keys Text edition CTRL + c : Copy the selected textCTRL + v : Paste the previously copied textCTRL + x : Cut the selected text (in order to move it)CTRL + s : Save your workCTRL + SHIFT + s : Save your work under a different filenameCTRL + h : Find and Replace - Allows you to replace every occurrences of a character string with another. Text navigation CTRL + f : Find some text in a text editor window or a web page. Navigation between applications ALT + TAB : Switches between applications (IDLE, Explorer, Web Browser...) Web Browser navigation : Those Shortcuts are the Firefox ones, but they (probably) exist for every browser, if they don't work for your browser, you can find the equivalents by doing a web search or cruising around the menus.CTRL + TAB : Switches between tabsCTRL + SHIFT + TAB : Switches in reverseCTRL + w : Closes the current tabCTRL + t : Open a new tabCTRL + SHIFT + T : Reopen the last closed tabCTRL + t , then TAB : Position you right in the web search bar Chapter 2 - Miscellaneous tips Never, [ever]\color{red}{\text{[ever]}} install anything that has "[Toolbar]\color{red}{\text{[Toolbar]}}" in its name

This exercise is about function reuse and how to apply a function to every characters in a string. A good example of a very similar use case is the implementation of the encryption step of a shift cipher. A shift cipher works by replacing each character in the input string by the character obtained if the first character is shifted by a number of places. So for example, "A" becomes "B" with a shift of 1. A shift cipher with a constant shift key of 1 could be implemented like this: def shift_one(char): ''' (str) -> str Returns the character obtained by shifting char one time to the right. >>> shift_one('A') 'B' >>> shift_one('B') 'C' ''' # Get the number corresponding to the character, add 1 to it, # and returns the character corresponding to that new number. return chr(ord(char) + 1)def get_encrypted_message(message): ''' (str) -> str Returns an encrypted version of message obtained by shifting every character one place to the right. >>> get_encrypted_message("AB") 'BC' >>> get_encrypted_message("BC") 'CD' ''' output = '' # Initialize the accumulator variable. for char in message: # For every character in message... output = output + shift_one(char) # ...add the shifted char to output. return output # When every char was added, return the result. >>> get_encrypted_message("This is a test!")'Uijt!jt!b!uftu"'Now, for the get_complementary_sequence code, instead of the shift_one function, you would be using the get_complementary function.

May I ask why you guys are sticking to such an historical version of the Caesar's Cipher? It certainly made sense at the time because Mr. Caesar did not have a handy tool such as ord() at his disposal and the only ordered sequence he could use was the letter sequence, but if you forget that limitation you can do something that's a little bit harder to decrypt and more fun too: >>> def caesar_encrypt(msg, key = 5):... '''(str, int)-> str... ... Return an encrypted version of message msg using a caesar-like cipher with... a shift dependant on the key and the length of the string.... ... Precondition: key is in the (arbitrary) range [O, 255]... ... '''... return ''.join([chr(ord(char) + key + len(msg) % key) for char in msg])... >>> def caesar_decrypt(msg, key = 5):... '''(str, int)-> str... ... Return an decrypted version of message msg using a caesar-like cipher with... a reverse shift dependant on the key and the length of the string.... ... Precondition: key is in the (arbitrary) range [O, 255]... ... '''... return ''.join([chr(ord(char) - key - len(msg) % key) for char in msg])... >>> scrambled = caesar_encrypt("This is a test!", 255)>>> scrambled'ŢŶŷƁĮŷƁĮůĮƂųƁƂį'>>> scrambled = caesar_encrypt("This is a test!!", 255)>>> scrambled # Notice how adding one character changes the shift.'ţŷŸƂįŸƂįŰįƃŴƂƃİİ'>>> caesar_decrypt(scrambled, 255)'This is a test!!'Cheers

Hello, Do you really need to set the default version? You can use Python3 easily by using the command "python3" and IDLE too using the command "idle3".

Also, if you want to execute a Python3 source file without having to write "python", you can add a shebang! line at the beginning of the file: File program.py: #!/usr/bin/env python3 print("Greetings, overlord.") And then, use the command chmod +x program.py to turn it into an executable file. Now, you can run the program with the command: ./program.py ouroumov@Adcap:~/Desktop$ chmod +x program.py ouroumov@Adcap:~/Desktop$ ./program.pyGreetings, overlord.ouroumov@Adcap:~/Desktop$ If you need to use a function that is in another file named, let's say, "module.py", then you can use the import statement: from module import * , this is roughly equivalent to using IDLE's "Run module" menu command: Files in the directory ouroumov@Adcap:~/Desktop/PyTest$ ls -Fmodule.py program.py* Module.py def f(x): return x ** 2x = 9 program.py #!/usr/bin/env python3from module import *print("Greetings, overlord.", f(4), f(x)) Result: ouroumov@Adcap:~/Desktop/PyTest$ ./program.pyGreetings, overlord. 16 81ouroumov@Adcap:~/Desktop/PyTest$

Just like, in our normal math system, we cannot express all the digits of 1/3 as a decimal number (without using extra notation), the normal representation of computers is unable to perfectly represent 13/7. And just like we often round, the computer also rounds. However, the computer uses a different base than we do (slightly different way of representing numbers) which means that sometimes the computer needs to round even if we don't, leading to surprising answers like the result of 0.1 * 3.

Python compares strings in the same order as you'd find in a dictionary (for example, "bobcat" appears before "meerkat" in a dictionary, so "bobcat" < "meerkat"). The exception is that an uppercase character always appears BEFORE lowercase equivalents. For example, "Zebra" appears before "apple" (or any other word that starts with a lowercase character).

(The following is just a for-fun explanation)The mathematical operator modulo can be either negative OR positive for negative numbers. For example, it is correct to say that -11 modulo 10 is both -1 or 9 (-11 is either -2 * 10 with 9 left over or -1 * 10 with -1 left over). For some purposes, it's more convenient to have a negative number and for others, a positive number. Different programming languages have settled on different ways of treating negative numbers; Python has chosen the always-positive route.

Idea in basic language is that say if two numbers a & b have the same modulo 24 value, then either a = b + m*24... or b = a + m*24, where m is the multiple of 24 that is required to make up the equality.In your example, 25 & 1 have the modulo 24 value of 1... &, sure enough, as expected: 1 + 24 = 25.Now, consider -1... it will have a modulo 24 value of 23... as, if you added 24 to -1, you'd get 23.You stop @ 23, as clearly adding another 24 will create a new problem.Finally, consider -134, for example, just keep adding 24s to it 'til you get to 10 & check that in python.

These kinds of issues that you seem to be having are common enough for people trying to learn programming, especially the 'understood it last week, don't understand it now' experience & the emotional reaction to that. So, feel good that all this trouble will be worth it in the end. =D.Now, my own brief explanation of a return statement: all functions are either called directly by you or by other functions. If called directly by you, it will return a value (which can, in fact, rather weirdly, be 'None'... think of 'None' as 'none of the other return values out there') to you. Yet, how do you directly call a function? For us, it's effectively always on IDLE, so what is returned to you is returned to you on the next line of IDLE, & the way IDLE displays that return on the next line of IDLE is by printing it... unless what's being returned is 'None', which doesn't get printed.If a function is not directly called by you (most won't be, you will find as you write more programs), it must have been called by another function... so function_1 calls function_2... & so function_2, when it completes, must return to function_1 (just as if it was returning to you directly, as if you had called it). What function_2 returns to function_1 is what is that return value.Now, function_1 will have been written by you (or someone else) to expect certain kinds of things to be returned & not others... the kind of thing is what we talk about when we talk about 'type'. If function_1 calls function_2 to read the temperature off your local newspaper's website, function_1 will expect function_2 to return a number, most likely a float. If function_1 is actually adding that temperature onto all the other temperatures of the past month to work out an 'average temperature over the past month', then you can see why function_1 will face problems if function_2 returns 'sunny' instead of a number.When we are talking about return values, we are essentially talking about considering how to make sure that no function_1 expecting a number from function_2 gets 'sunny' instead... A function can, amazingly, return another function... but I will only talk about that if you tell me that you've found any of the above helpful.I hope it helps, I'm not sure it will, but I hope it does.

Is it 8 = dollars that is false or 8 == dollars that is false? I'm surprised that 8 = dollars doesn't raise a syntax error.If you meant '8 == dollars' is false, while '8 >= dollars' is true... well, then: 8 == dollars is testing for whether dollars equals 8 (in magnitude), while 8 >= dollars is testing for whether dollars is less than or equal to 8 (in magnitude).Clearly, if dollars is 7, 6, 5 or any number less than 8, then it's true that dollars is "less than or equal to" 8, but it's not true that dollars is "equal" to 8.& if you consider 8 <= dollars, one is testing there for whether dollars is "greater than or equal to" 8.I hope this helps.

Here is the result of executing that code in the Python shell:
>>> print('a', 'b', 'c', sep=', ', end='')a, b, c>>> print('a', 'b', 'c', sep=', ')a, b, c>>>
Notice that in the second line the prompt (>>>) appears right after the c. That is because the end parameter refers to the empty string. In the 2nd print function call, a newline character (\n) is used as the default end character, so there is a newline after the c and the prompt appears on the next line.

The order of the statements is really important. At the point when the second assignment statement (x = abs(x)) is executed, the value that x refers to is 10. Therefore, y refers to 10. When the third assignment statement is executed, the value that x refers to changes to 11, but y is not impacted by this change.It may help to trace this code in the Python Visualizer (see the Resources page).

There are now 42 test cases. A test case involves calling your function and checking the value returned to make sure it matches what we expect. For example, let's say that there is a function named add that takes two arguments. I might call it likes this add(2, 3) and I'd expect the function to return 5. If it does, then we say that the test case passes.If your submission has a score of 42, then it has passed all test cases and you are done!

A parameter is a variable that appears between the parentheses in a function header, and an argument is an expression that appears between the parentheses of a function call.>>> def area(base, height): # <-- Here, base and height are parameters.... return base * height / 2... >>> h = 4>>> area(3, h) # <-- Here, area is called with the arguments 3 and h.6.0
There must be 2 underscores ('_') on each side of the word builtins:>>> dir(__builtins__)

The rules for executing a return statement: Evaluate the expression. This produces a memory address. Pass back that memory address to the caller. Exit the function. Notice that last part of step 2: "Exit the function." As part of the execution of the first return statement, the function exits, so the second return statement is not reached and isn't executed.

This is perhaps the best explanation so far I've seen of this question, Gerrit!The two defined functions count_vowels( ) and count_consonants( ) are the ones you need to call in your new function, count_letters( ). If you add them together, you will get the number of letters in (word).Now, the question is how exactly do you add two functions together inside a third function.That's what you need to figure out.

Absolutely, I think you've found the answer as posted below. None (with a capital N) is defined as a type in Python, but none (all lower) is not, so it doesn't know what you're doing when you are trying to define x = none.

The difference between Question 5 and Question 6 is the behavior of this line:>>> instructor_location = announce_location('Canada')In Question 5, it simply stores something in memory and doesn't produce any output.In Question 6, it prints 'Canada' to the console.So, the question is, what would you put into the body of the function to cause this difference in behavior?

an or requires at least one thing to be true.answer 1 was "the student passed none of the courses". That would be three falses, so the end result would be false. answer 2 was "the student passed at least one of the courses." That would mean at least one thing is true, so the or would be true too.answer 3 was "the student passed all of the courses." Maybe they didn't, maybe they only passed two. True+true+false. It would give a true result, but it's not necessary to get all three to work with an or. So you don't need to tick that box.answer 4 was "the student passed some but not all of the courses." Maybe they did, making true+true+true, which would give a true for an or, but it is not essential to have all three. Remember only one would do. So you don't have to tick this box either.
yes, that's right, if you are using or, then true+false+true is true. It only needs one thing to be true. It's the and that needs everything to be true.

Case#1 math=60, bio=20, cs=30, the Boolean expression will be True. (one pass) - only if it is an or you are evaluating. It won't be true for an and.if Case#2 math=60, bio=70, cs=30, the Boolean expression will be True also. (two passed) - same as case#1. Only works with or.if Case#3 math=60, bio=70, cs=80, the Boolean expression will be True also. (all passed) - this will be true for both and and or.

"The student passed all of the courses" is false if maths and cs are true, but bio is false."The student passed some but not all of the courses" is also false, because they might have passed all three.The only correct solution is "the student passed at least one of the courses".For the and, the only true output is true+true+trueFor the or, which is what we are discussing, the only false output is false+false+false. Everything else equates to true.

>= and <= are not assignment statements. They are used for making comparisons. The longhand is -is the maths grade equal to or more than 50? same for the the bio and cs grades too. Each of these will evaluate to either true, or false.So you will end up with three trues, or three falses, or a combination of trues and falses.Now look at the logical operator. Is it and or or?The and needs all three things to be true.The or needs at least one of them to be true. (But not none of them. It needs at least one.)

Here's mine without the docstrings.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~def get_length(dna):   return len(dna)def is_longer(dna1, dna2):    return len(dna1)> len(dna2)   def count_nucleotides(dna, nucleotide):   total = 0   count = 0   for char in dna:       current = dna[count]       count = count+ 1       if nucleotide ==(current):           total = total+1   return total          def contains_sequence(dna1, dna2):   return (dna2 in dna1)def is_valid_sequence(dna):   is_valid = True   count = 0   for char in dna:       current = dna[count]       count = count+ 1       if not current in 'ATCG':           is_valid = False return is_validdef insert_sequence(dna1, dna2, pos):   new_string = ''   first_part = dna1[0:pos]   last_part = dna1[pos:len(dna1)]   new_string = first_part +dna2+last_part   return new_stringdef get_complement(nucleotide):   if 'A' in nucleotide:       return 'T'   elif 'C' in nucleotide:       return 'G'   elif 'G' in nucleotide:       return 'C'   elif 'T' in nucleotide:       return 'A'   else:       return 'Invalid data entered!'def get_complementary_sequence(dna):   complement = ''   current = ''   if is_valid_sequence(dna) == True:       for count in dna:           current = get_complement(count)           complement = complement + current   else:       complement = 'Invalid sequence entered!'   return complement

This is mine without the docstrings.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~def seconds_difference(time_1, time_2):   difference = time_2 - time_1   return difference   def hours_difference(time_1, time_2):   difference = (time_2 - time_1)/3600   return differencedef to_float_hours(hours, minutes, seconds):   total_hours = hours + (minutes/60) + (seconds/3600)   return total_hoursdef to_24_hour_clock(hours):   return hours % 24def get_hours(seconds):   whole_hours = seconds // 3600   return whole_hoursdef get_minutes(seconds):   seconds_remaining = seconds % 3600   whole_minutes = seconds_remaining // 60   return whole_minutesdef get_seconds(seconds):   remainder1 = seconds % 3600   remainder2 = remainder1 % 60   return remainder2def time_to_utc(utc_offset, time):   UTC0_time = time - utc_offset   return to_24_hour_clock(UTC0_time)   def time_from_utc(utc_offset, time):   UTC_time = time + utc_offset   return to_24_hour_clock(UTC_time)

I was just explaining stacks today to some of my engineering students, who code in assembler and could not be called experienced programmers by anybody's standards (they are a nice group and do try very hard, though).in assembler, you mostly have to move values about between registers. Let's say you added two numbers, and the answer is in the AH register. You want to output the answer to the screen, but the graphics card also uses the AH register. If you try to output anything, you will end up overwriting the answer.So you "push" the answer, in AH, onto the stack, to keep it safe. You then use the AH register to do the display bit. Then you "pop" the stack to bring back the answer, and carry on from where you left off.You can have many items in the stack but they always go on top of each other, and are removed again in a LIFO (last in, first out) order. You can't change the order of things once they are on a stack. If you try to remove an item from an already empty stack, you get an underflow. If you haven't allowed enough room for your stack at the start, it can overflow (everything just dumps and crashes and you usually get the Blue Screen Of Death). And experienced programmers do quite often use tools like the visualiser to step through code, but they are usually called debugging tools. They are not always separate from the main development interface, sometimes it's just a step-through option, but it's the same sort of thing. It enables you to run your code a line at a time so you can see exactly where it falls over.

also look at some of the other file modes Modes	Description r	Opens a file for reading only. The file pointer is placed at the beginning of the file. This is the default mode. rb	Opens a file for reading only in binary format. The file pointer is placed at the beginning of the file. This is the default mode. r+	Opens a file for both reading and writing. The file pointer will be at the beginning of the file. rb+	Opens a file for both reading and writing in binary format. The file pointer will be at the beginning of the file. w	Opens a file for writing only. Overwrites the file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for writing. wb	Opens a file for writing only in binary format. Overwrites the file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for writing. w+	Opens a file for both writing and reading. Overwrites the existing file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for reading and writing. wb+	Opens a file for both writing and reading in binary format. Overwrites the existing file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for reading and writing. a	Opens a file for appending. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. That is, the file is in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for writing. ab	Opens a file for appending in binary format. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. That is, the file is in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for writing. a+	Opens a file for both appending and reading. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. The file opens in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for reading and writing. ab+	Opens a file for both appending and reading in binary format. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. The file opens in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for reading and writing.

they want to turn this['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']into this['ab', 'cd']the code to do it is there your goal is to pick the answer listed below that will complete the functionappend(L[i] + L[i + 1])does the worki is the variable that we need to change to do the workwhen we start i = 0in the list ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']"a" is at index 0and"b" is at index 1so in the above append lets just look at it with number in place of i for a secondappend(L[0] + L[0 + 1])this will get the "a" and the "b" make a new string "ab" and append it to the other list empty listnow we just need to step to the other indexes in the first list,we took care of indexes 0 and 1and i still is at 0so now we just need to increment i to get to the next spot we want, but that is more then one away,which answer of the 4 would do that for you? test them and see the results

if you think that range(1) is [0] and that range(2) is a list consisting of 1 and 2 then the code and your understanding or the way that it has been explained to you is the problem, 0 is not 1 and 2 is not [1,2] and if you say "Absolutely nobody is arguing over what the code means or what the code does or what range means."then why must you go on and give an incorrect statement regarding what a range is and what a range contains.it does not precisely contain integers, a range is a sequence of numbers. arranged in a list. the number can be integers or floats, and what is in them is determined by the start, stop and step arguments, or if omitted their default values. range will generate a sequence of numbers based on these values, range(10) will generate the sequence 0-9 10 different values, range(10) is the same as range(0,10,1) because the default values for start and step are omitted.and since the end value is exclusive the sequence is 0-9 not 1-10, because once again 0 does not equal 1, just because you start counting at 0 does not change the value or meaning of a number, it just means that you start counting in a different place.

because b = a is not a copy, b equals a is the result. strings are immutable so making changes to one does not change the other, a = "abc"b = aa = a + "d"a"abcd"b"abc"above b is not changes because a is reassigned and not mutatedlists on the other hand can be mutated, and mutation is not reassignmentreassignment of a list examplea = [1, 2, 3]b = aa[1,2,3]b[1,2,3]a = [4,5,6]a[4,5,6]b[1,2,3]mutation examplea = [1,2,3]b = aa[1,2,3]b[1,2,3]a[0]=4a[4,2,3]b[4,2,3]in mutation we make a change and because lists are mutable both lists will changein reassignment we make a change to the first nothing will happen to the second, because the second equals the list that the first one was pointing to, and the first one points to a new listside note, a simple way to copy is to use slicing, just make the slice the entire list. this is just another way,a = [1,2,3]b = a[:]a[0] = 4a[4,2,3]b[1,2,3] ora new assignment of list * 1c = b * 1b[2]=33b[1,2,33]c[1,2,3]

Crash course in a simple for loop and review on some other things we have learned already A for loop is a simple concept Basic for a in range(10): Means we will look at every number between 0 and 9 (Python starts at 0) and each time the variable "a" will equal one of the values until we reach the last in the range (with Python that is the number -1, still 10 values, just 0 through 9 instead of 1 through 10). for a in range(10): print(a) will print 0123456789 An Enhanced for loop look like this examplefor letter in word:So it will loop over each letter in a wordword = 'Hello'for letter in word: print(letter)Hellonow do you remember ord() and chr() from the videosand how they work with the ascii table http://www.asciitable.com/and the modules operator %and from the quizzes, how to build stringsword = 'a' + 'a' word = chr(65) + char(65) word = word + 'a' word = 'ba'+ na * 2 + ' muffin'etc....and you remember how to define a functionall this and a little math and you can have a working Caesar cipher.

from tkinter import *# import math moved outside of the function import math# Function modified to take 0 argument# Argument are not retrived directley from the Entry boxesdef acimuth(): """(num) -> (num) Return the acimuth between two points. >>> acimut(50000, 40000, 58000, 48000) The acimuth is 45.0 >>> acimut(58000, 40000, 50000, 48000) The acimuth is 135.0 >>> acimut(58000, 48000, 50000, 40000) The acimuth is 225.0 >>> acimut(50000, 48000, 58000, 40000) The acimuth is 315.0 """ # This is a way to get the values from your Entry boxes  # Default for Entry boxes  Norte1 = int(nombre_entry.get()) Norte2 = int(mail_entry.get()) Este1 = int(last_entry.get()) Este2 = int(mail_entry2.get()) #Calculate of Delta East Deltaeste= Este2 - Este1 #Calculate of Delta North Deltanorth= Norte2 - Norte1 #Calculate of Delta East divided by Delta North eastovernorth= Deltaeste/Deltanorth #Calculate of Rumbo en radianes Rumbo1= math.atan(eastovernorth) #Calculate of Rumbo en grados Rumbo2= Rumbo1*180/math.pi # Modified to set the outcome to a control variable # See explanation below if Deltaeste>0 and Deltanorth>0: result.set(Rumbo2) if Deltaeste>0 and Deltanorth<0: result.set(180 + Rumbo2) if Deltaeste<0 and Deltanorth<0: result.set(180 + Rumbo2) if Deltaeste<0 and Deltanorth>0: result.set(360 + Rumbo2) # This updates the canvas to display the results root.update_idletasks()  root = Tk()root.title('Geo version Demo')# Adjusted window geometry root.geometry("400x200")# Set a control variable for results # Result is used to display the results of calling the function# To get a control variable, use one of these class constructors, depending on what type of values you need to store in it:# v = tk.DoubleVar() # Holds a float; default value 0.0# v = tk.IntVar() # Holds an int; default value 0# v = tk.StringVar() # Holds a string; default value ''result = DoubleVar()# row 1 nombre_label = Label(root,text=" Coordenada Norte del punto 1 :")nombre_label.grid(row=1,column=1)nombre_entry = Entry(root)nombre_entry.grid(row=1,column=2)#row 2 last_label= Label(root,text="Coordenada Este del punto 1 : ")last_label.grid(row=2,column=1)last_entry = Entry(root)last_entry.grid(row=2,column=2)#row 3 mail_label = Label(root,text=" Coordenada Norte del punto 2 : ")mail_label.grid(row=3,column=1)mail_entry = Entry(root)mail_entry.grid(row=3,column=2)#row 4 mail_label2 = Label(root,text="Coordenada Este del punto 2 : ")mail_label2.grid(row=4,column=1)mail_entry2 = Entry(root)mail_entry2.grid(row=4,column=2)# Command calles the function, but you need to pass argument to the function# The original function was modified to get the arguments from the Entry boxes# row 5finish = Button(root,text="Acimut", command=acimuth)finish.grid(row=5,column=2)# Added 2 labels to display the results of the function# Row 6result_label1 = Label(root, text = "The acimuth is")result_label1.grid(row = 6, column = 2)# Row 7result_label2 = Label(root, textvariable = result)result_label2.grid(row = 7, column = 2)root.mainloop()

leave the working functions alone, create a "Control Function" to handle the workdef start (A, B, C): Z = A+B/C return A, B, Zdef test_1 (Z, B): X = (Z*Z) - B return Xdef test_2 (X, Z, A): Q = X+Z+A return Qdef final (A, B, C, Z, X, Q): print A, B, C, Z, X, Qdef controlFunction(a, b, c): A, B, Z = start(a, b, c) X = test_1(Z, B) Q = test_2(X, Z, A) final(A, B, c, Z, X, Q)Fixed the typo

if you read some of the above post you see how the str.find() method works.lets start there,if I have a string stored in a variablemy_string = "Hello Sandy, My sister name Sandy too" if I want to find the substring "Sandy" in the above, I use the find commandmy_string.find("Sandy")this will return the index of the first occurrence of "Sandy" which is 6, six because the indexes starts at 0find has 2 optional arguments start and end, self explanatory as to what they mean, but lets look at how to use themmy_string.find("Sandy", 0)if we use a 0 for the start, find will start looking at index 0 for 'Sandy', and it will keep looking until it find 'Sandy' at index 6, and then it will return the int 6 to us.if we say my_string.find("Sandy", 5)well that is going to give us the same result because the first 'Sandy' is at 6, so starting at 5 just means that we skip looking at 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 and start at 5my_string.find("Sandy", 7)well Sandy is at 6 so if we start looking at 7, do you think we will find Sandy, No Sandy starts at 6, at 7 we find andy,so we keep looking and all the way down at 28 we find the next SandySo my_string.find("Sandy") found the first Sandy located at index 6and my_string.find("Sandy", 7) found the second Sandy located down at index 28so what we did was take my_string.find("Sandy") and add 1remember my_string.find("Sandy") = 6 and 6 + 1 = 7 so if you take my_string.find("Sandy") add one and combine it with my_string.find("Sandy", 7) to find the second Sandymy_string.find("Sandy", ????)

you know that in the example I posted above 10 could be replaced by something else say something like a string method that would .find() the index of the first string, a = 'hello hello hello' If I did a.find('hello') It would give me the number 0, because 'hello' first occurs at index 0 a.find('hello',1) 1 because it is the first spot after the h in hello and ello does not match so now it looks for the next hello would return 6 try this code and see what you get a = 'hello hello hello'a.find('hello')+1 what result did you see now look at this and think about what the result and this next line share. could you use something in place of the 1 below, maybe combine the 2 things. a.find('hello',1)

Actually, it can be done in one line. the str.count() method count(...) S.count(sub[, start[, end]]) -> int Return the number of non-overlapping occurrences of substring sub in string S[start:end]. Optional arguments start and end are interpreted as in slice notation.just omit the options

Jennifer, yes 0+1 is 1 that is the point of that part, and the reason to add 1 is to use that as the index to start searching again. if you start at the same point that the first finds results you will find the same first match, but if you just step it by 1 then it will skip that index (and the first result) and look for the next occurrence. a.find('hello',1) a = 'hello hello hello' a.find('hello') <--- finds the first hello a.find('hello')+1 <--- is the index of the first hello + 1, a.find('hello', 1) <-- this will start looking at index 1 for hello, since the first hello start at 0 it will not find the first hello, so it will keep looking and find the second hello. so if you combined a .find(string, start_index) and a .find() you Can find the second hello. Tkinter is compatible between python2 and python3. Here look at this. http://www.codeskulptor.org/#user14_y2Q4BAFRsP_1.py I wrote it for An Introduction to Interactive Programming in Python back in May, it will run on python2 or python3. The tkiner code is the same for both python versions. The only exception for the different versions of python is the import lines, other then that they share all the same tk code.   try:  # this is for python 2.7       from tkinter import *   except ImportError:     # this is for python 3.3       from Tkinter import *

the short way Import string def getMap(key): ext = ''.join([chr(a) for a in range(161,256)]) map = string.printable + ext keyMap = map[key:] + map[:key] keyMap = keyMap[key:] + keyMap[:key] return map,keyMap def encrypt(message, key, crypt): key = key + len(message) if crypt[0].lower() == 'd': key *= -1 key,keyMap = getMap(key) message = message.translate(str.maketrans(key, keyMap)) else: key,keyMap = getMap(key) message = message.translate(str.maketrans(key, keyMap))  return message  Message = "Hello World!" newMessage = encrypt(message, 10, 'encode') print(newMessage) oldmessage = encrypt(newMessage, 10, 'decode') print(oldmessage)

exactly like below def report_status(scheduled_time, estimated_time): ''' (number, number) -> str Return the flight status (on time, early, delayed) for a flight that was scheduled to arrive at scheduled_time, but is now estimated to arrive at estimated_time. Pre-condition: 0.0 <= scheduled_time < 24 and 0.0 <= estimated_time < 24 >>>report_status(14.3, 14.3) 'on time' >>>report_status(12.5, 11.5) 'early' >>>report_status(9.0, 9.5) 'delayed' ''' if scheduled_time == estimated_time: return 'on time' elif scheduled_time > estimated_time: return 'early' else: return 'delayed'

let me post the steps to make this function work and some explanations to the stepsstep 1. create a temp variable and set it to and empty stringstep 2. create a for loop to loop over the rows in the board step 3. add to the temp variable the character located in the row at the column indexstep 4. return the temp variableexplanation of stepsstep 1. is just creating a variable (you can use any name that you want) and making that variable = "" refer to week 2 lecture notes for more details https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/programming1/lecture_summaries%2Fweek2%2Fstr.htmlstep 2. I will point you to the week 4 lecture notes  https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/programming1/lecture_summaries%2Fweek4%2Ffor.html the notes use strings, but you will do the exact same thing for a list aList = ['hello', 'this', 'is', 'a', 'list'] for word in list: print(word) hello this is a list you just need to change in the for loop the example to work with the rows in the board:step 3. again I will refer you to the lecture notes, this time week 2  https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/programming1/lecture_summaries%2Fweek2%2Fstr.html look at the section "String Operators" near the bottom of the page and the lecture notes from week 4 https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/programming1/lecture_summaries%2Fweek4%2Findexing.html again the week 4 lecture notes are for strings but it is done in the same way for lists  aList = ['hello', 'this', 'is', 'a', 'list'] print the word at index 2 in the above list print(aList[2]) 'is' print the word at index 0 in the above list print(aList[0]) 'hello' what we want to do is take that temp variable in step 1 and then use it to accumulate the result to this variable example temp = '' aList = ['hello', 'this', 'is', 'a', 'list'] temp = temp + aList[4] print(temp) 'list' temp = temp + aList[3] print(temp) 'lista' note there are no spaces in the list so "list" and "a" become one word with no spaces temp = temp +aList[2]  temp = temp +aList[1] temp = temp +aList[0] print(temp) 'listaisthishello' if we use a for loop to do this it might look like this temp = "" for word in aList: temp = temp + word print(temp) 'hellothisisalist' the only thing to remember that will be different is that you do not want to add the whole word to your temp variable you just want to get the 1 character from the row at the [column_index] and add that to the temp variable, and that is covered in the lecture notes under string indexingstep 4. you do have it. the answer is 0str.count('ATCG')ATCG does not appear in ATTGCCThe misunderstanding is of what the sub string isthe sub string you are counting is an exact match to a small part of the string in your above example str.count('A' + 'T' + 'C' + 'G') is the same as str.count('ATCG')so that means you are looking for "ATCG" in "ATTGCC" and "ATCG" is not in "ATTGCC" lets shift to a more clear examplegreetings = "Hello Ning and Hello to everyone else"now we have a string greetings with different words in itlets count the number of time the sub string "Hello" is in our stringgreetings.count("Hello")2the count looks for an exact match to the sub string for both upper and lower case letter, the order of the letter and the same number of letterslets change greetings, say that I did not capitalize the second "Hello" greetings = "Hello Ning and hello to everyone else"now if we run the same count commandgreetings.count("Hello")1it will only return 1, because there is only 1 exact match.
